title: Vintage movie subtitles - taking suggestions
content: I'm an independent filmmaker and my current short is a black & white homage to '60s French new wave films. I'm trying to simulate the look of subtitles from the pre-DVD, pre-closed-captioned era. Any suggestions? Thanks.
author: anonymous

comments.content:
I became interested in the concept of type design for subtitles a few months ago. In my phase of cramming as much information on the subject as possible, I discovered that there is one handsdown expert on the subject--Joe Clark. Go to his site: [www.joeclark.org](http://web.archive.org/web/20150312165024/http:/www.joeclark.org/)   
   
When you get there you can either browse the seemingly endless resources he provides, or you can email him with your question and I'll bet he can answer it.

I must say I don't really know what they should look like.   
Do you have any visual examples that you could show us?

Make them hard to read and that should do it ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150312165024im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/clipart/wink.gif)   
   
Seriously, though, I wonder if a typerwriter font like courier would work. Subtitles were pretty primitive back then I believe.   
   
Or are you looking for more of a nouvelle vague style for the type
